comments.commentBody:
If you look at Aker's kicking action, you'll see that he is the only kicker in the game who has the same action for a kick off and a on-side kick. Its truly amazing. You really cant make out the type of kick that is coming.

I wouldnt blame coughlin. If anything its an execution problem wtih the Giants Special Teams. They have to figure out Aker's tell, if he has one.

You just have to credit Akers on this... He must practice this like crazy to make both kicks with exactly the same action.

This is no surprise. Low skills are hourly waged, and have a relatively flat career plan. Leaving and coming back only means the opportunity cost of hours not worked.

On the other hand, high skill jobs have career tracks long laid by men with wives who looked after the home front for them, and the mechanics of that (tenure, partnership, management and technical tracks) have only slowly evolved recently to account for a period of childrearing. The opportunity cost is therefore very high.

Was no one looking at the game clock which they showed went  to 00 as Jackson was sitll running paralel to the end zone and had not crossed the goal line, thus the game should have gone into overtime. How could anyone miss it.

I still say Shottenheimer needs to be fired. Yes, they won, but the offense still didn't take off, the way it could if Shottenheimer was a good coach. Yes! What about using Smith as a passer? And why did it take so long for them to utilize Sanchez's ability to play fake? The bottom line: the offensive weapons the Jets have are beyond the ability of their offensive coach to employ. It's like taking a guy off the street and putting him behind the wheel of a Maserati - a pro driver would beat him driving a VW! I know we're probably stuck with him until the end of the season, but they gotta get rid of him before next year!

I don't see that women who want to spend time with their children are penalized.

I see that women (and men) are financially rewarded for work being their top priority, more important than family, relationships, leisure time, etc.

It is not the way I want to spend my life, but I see no reason they should not be rewarded for coming in early and leaving late every day, while I work only 9-5.

Lets continue to penalize highly skilled, trained women who spend time with their children.

Just brilliant.

And all of the management schools and all of the men in charge couldn't come up with a better plan than this?

While the higher earning mother may pay a 'higher price'; this article fails to mention that the same high-income family has already reached an certain level of financial comfort, even luxury, compared to the lower earning family or mother. So the comparison is quite absurd; there is no way to compare the 'price paid' in real terms. Dollars do not have the same value for each of us; because the higher your income, the less difference each dollar makes.

This article makes me reflect on who values money more than love, life and family... Living in Europe for many years, I have witnessed the change in the quality of life because educated couples can't "afford" children.  That one child produced is a spoiled brat, and at that, there aren't enough of them to keep up the social security net in Italy, France....
As a sidebar, remember, the non-economic benefits of remaining childless are enormous, too.

Back when the economy allowed such things as middle managers, I supervised many young, well educated professional women.
It always seemed to me that the birth of a child, especially the first one, changed the woman's perspective in ways she could not predict before the birth.
Many women, who had said they would be back to full-time work as soon as they could, never came back. Others just dabbled, using job-sharing arrangements or part-time opportunities to keep their skills up and their sanity.
Still others who said they were going to take a year's leave of absence -- permitted by the company -- were back in six weeks, as if they couldn't bear the financial or emotional costs of staying home all day.
Of course, most women stuck to the course they had developed before the birth, but plenty bore out the truth of the dictum: "Life is what happens when you are busy making other plans."
As to the study's conclusion, people who make a lot of money have a lot to lose. People who don't make any money, have nothing to lose. It's not surprising the opportunity costs are higher for higher income women.

David, Thanks for the report on the  sacrifices of motherhood, not really that interesting to me, but it did spark this thought: As a husband and wife team of 35 years Karen and I were blessed with 12 children, 11 still living. The rewards of having a big family to enjoy, especially in our senior years, with the eight grandchildren, and our youngest boy is only eleven, can not be matched in any amount of silver or gold. Did my wife give anything up for her children? Or is it better to ask the question to the childless wife: How much did you get for keeping your nest empty?

And yet, these high achieving woman are precisely the ones who (we hope) are having children who go on to be achievers.

This is an interesting study but should not deter women from having children. Women know that having children changes their lives and there is much sacrifice. That is unlikely to change now or in the future.

Now, if quality and affordable child care were available across all the board, that would be news and would reduce the impact on these high achieving women's lives and careers.

50% of marriages end in divorce and it is very rare for a father to end up the custodial parent, no matter how much he wants to be the custodial parent.

Therefore one wonders what percentage of the measured impact is due to the custodial parent imbalance, and how including child support would affect the "mommy gap"?

I'd also guess that the "daddy gap", for those of us fortunate to be the custodial parent, is at least as large as the "mommy gap". However, speaking only for myself, the "daddy gap" is worth every penny; my time with my child is far more precious than money.

Perhaps the paper addresses these issues, but it's behind a pay wall for the majority of us.

Are the higher skilled women leaving the workforce after having children?  Are they working reduced hours after having children? For women who go back to work full time, are their wages subject to fewer raises? How does the lack of quality, affordable child care factor in to this situation?  Would women of all skill levels be positively impacted by increasing the availability of quality, affordable child care?

I was surprised by this article because it completely dismisses the role women in the divorce rate. Most women file for divorce (~70%) --- not men. Yet, in many cases, the reasons for divorce are related to the fact that they have offspring from another guy. Doesn't this mix up economic situation?

Given the fact that much of my academic career has been under the tutelage of women, I wonder if NOW is the time for woman to take responsibility for creating this imbalance?

Women who stay at home with children lose income.

Men who work lose time with their children.

No one can have it all.

It is about choice. You can have a career or you can be a mom. You can do only right. Why is it that when it comes to abortion women claim it is their right to do with their body what they want, but when it comes time to choose career or motherhood then the world is sexist? Seems hypocritical to me. As for men paying a lesser price, well that is pure bunk. Statistically we die much younger. Why? From the pressures of having to go to work to care of our family. For constantly having NO CHOICE once we do have a family. Let's see how enlightened women are. Tell your spouse when she gets pregnant that you are going to stay home and raise the child. You are an enlightened, new millennium male who wants to bond with his child. Tell her during that time she will be financially responsible for everything. See if that flies. Studies and papers such as yours continue to perpetuate the myth. Men pay no price? Tell that to every guy who worked himself to death to support his family. It was HIS responsibility, now it can be HERS.

By the way, the grand prize entry (credit score that also reflects savings rate) would disadvantage low-income people, as well as middle-income families struggling in this recession.

And how often do people pay attention to their FICO scores? Right - not often, unless you're shopping for a loan for a car or house. But by then, you've built up a down payment already (or should have), so you already have a way to demonstrate your savings habit in a way that is RELEVANT.

The wrong idea won the grand prize, and well, the mechanism for picking the people's choice award is just an online popularity contest. Most people aren't going to be able to judge whether a idea is really good or bad policy.

With interest rates at zero, there is no return on savings or money market accounts so why should someone save into a savings or money market account instead of investing it into an IRA?  It mostly makes sense to have savings for emergencies, but saving a lot of money when you can get a better return from other investments doesn't make any sense at all.

As stated by poster 1, interest rates are the key. Unless the interest rate on savings is at least 3 or 4%, there's no incentive to save.

Bring back the old US Savings Bonds. Right now only fat cats can invest in US Treasury bonds, which are paying around 4% right now. Sell Savings Bonds to people and pay 4% on the bonds. Use the old payroll option to make it easy for people to buy the bonds.

The credit score gimmick will never work. And the poster above who criticized the whole effort at increasing the savings rate right now is absolutely right - at this time we need spending, not savings, and we need jobs to have money to spend.

Apparently this is all too complicated for the dunce Obama, but anyone of average intelligence can easily understand it. The Federal government needs to spend, not continue the Reagan-Bush voodoo economics of tax cuts tax cuts tax cuts.

Don't tax interest on savings.. or tax it as cap gains NOT as earned income.

However, who wrote this piece? Don't you know that everyone is supposed to either buy gold or buy stock? (which is why there is a negative interest rate? -- contrary to Bernanke there is inflation -- on stuff like food, transportation -- not part of the index. But this is the guy who wants to cure the inequities in the economy via inflation. (not taxation which can work just as well...)

It is very simple to raise the savings rate and become a millionaire in the process. The first step is to stop buying presents for everyone, they never like them anyway and all the gas saved by not having to return things will save the planet. You know those nice fluffy towels you like to dry off with! Forget them, they take too much electricity to dry. Throw the cellphone out, if you forget the bread on this trip to the store, you'll surely remember it next trip and your mother can do without hearing from you for a couple of hours. You're already on your way to Savers Heaven.

A few years ago, when credit cards were being offered by banks to anyone, we tried to get my mother-in-law to apply for a second credit card through our cautious credit union. (She pays off her existing, very low maximum, bank-card every month, so this was to get her a better deal and as a back-up/higher maximum for travel, not to increase her borrowing.) She was turned down. We thought it was hilarious.

Part of the problem was she didn't list her main sources of income—her late husband's pension and an annuity, which more than cover her expenses. But there was absolutely nowhere to indicate the substantial amount she has in savings, including 20x the credit card's maximum in the credit union to which she was applying.

I have no idea whether using savings for credit scores would get people to save more—I think the low savings rate mostly reflects lack of sufficient income to cover expenses and, for many of those who do have enough income for discretionary spending or savings, a shop-till-you-drop mentality egged on by our commercial culture and without which the economy would collapse.
Sounds like a cool idea...if you earn enough to save anything.

Are holdings in mutual funds such as stock market and bond market index funds included in savings ?   What about savings in retirement accounts ?  It's an interesting idea.  It seems savers won't really get outside recognition for their virtue, but must be satisfied in their own mind by the outcomes.

Cash flow plus credit is the new paradigm for wealth.  Saving or encouraging savings is swimming against the tide.  Savings are to be discouraged because lending is funded by money substitutes backed by promises, a sort of Unreal Bills Doctrine.  The profits of banks are generated by fees and commission based product sales.  A savings account is simply to get you in the door.  To pay cash is to be a banking deadbeat. Credit scores were always the stick, not the carrot, this will not change, as nobody wants a borrower with a perfect credit score.

Our government ---

a) keeps interest rates down, thus punishing savers and rewarding debtors
b) demonizes people who have been successful savers and investors as the greedy "rich"
c) means-tests Medicare premiums, eligibility for many tax deductions, eligibility for Roth IRAs, and taxability of Social Security payments
d) espouses "spreading the wealth around", i.e. taking money from savers and giving it to non-savers.

With all these disincentives, saving doesn't make much sense, does it?
